p: The treatment of invasive fungal infections (IFIs) remains a major challenge worldwide. There are few broad-spectrum antifungal drugs; the most effective have substantial toxicity concerns, and well-tolerated drugs used prophylactically frequently induce resistance. Even with the best current treatment, the risk for mortality due to an IFI can be higher than 40%. For low-income countries, this figure is substantially worse, as many invasive infections are uniformly fatal without treatment, and estimates of global mortality involving fungal infections are as high as 1.5 million annually [ 87â€“ 89]. In addition, fungal infections are the cause of significant comorbidity and mortality in HIV patients. Modeling studies suggest that optimal therapy could save the lives of 1.6 million HIV patients over a 5-year period [ 90].
